item.title: Live Updates: Ukraine Claims to Shoot Down Several Russian Missiles
item.description: Officials in Kyiv warned of more attacks, a day after Russia’s broadest assault on Ukraine in months. Leaders of the Group of 7 nations held an emergency meeting on the conflict.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damaged buildings in Zaporizhzhia on Monday, after a Russian missile strike on Sunday.

item.title: One Nation Under Xi: How China’s Leader Is Remaking Its Identity
item.description: The leader’s nationalist effort to meld ethnic groups, an agenda increasingly central to his rule, is seen as a bulwark against internal divisions and threats from the West.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Yao Dawei/Xinhua, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, meeting with members of ethnic groups in 2015.

item.title: Israel and Lebanon Reach Landmark Maritime Agreement
item.description: If ratified by both governments, the deal is expected to avert the immediate threat of conflict between Israel and Hezbollah, and could eventually help salve energy shortages.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Jalaa Marey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An Israeli navy vessel patrolled the Mediterranean waters off Rosh Hanikra on the border between Israel and Lebanon on Friday.

item.title: With Attacks on Ukraine, Putin Gives Hard-Liners What They Wanted
item.description: A sharp shift toward deadly strikes signaled that domestic pressure over Russia’s flailing war effort had escalated to the point where Vladimir Putin felt a decisive show of force was necessary.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency services workers on Monday at the site of an overnight missile strike in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine.

item.title: Russian Strikes Batter Kyiv and Send Residents Dashing for Cover
item.description: The fighting in Ukraine had felt far from the capital in recent months, but the barrage of missiles brought many residents back to the fear and uncertainty of the early days of Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Megan Specia and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Injured civilians in Kyiv.

item.title: In Southern Ukraine, Signs of Low Russian Morale Amid Retreat
item.description: The Ukrainians are making gains in the south, an area where Russian soldiers are dug in more securely and where their retreat has been less chaotic than in the north.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers riding in a captured Russian military vehicle in Velyka Oleksandrivka last week.

item.title: Putin Unleashes Barrage of Missiles on Ukrainian Civilian Areas
item.description: The Russian president tied the attack to a bombing of the bridge to Crimea, and vowed that more strikes would follow if Russian targets were hit again.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Andrew E. Kramer, Megan Specia and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising over Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, on Monday after the Russian bombardment.

item.title: U.K.’s Young Hobbled by Inflation
item.description: Sharp price spikes are forcing the country’s young to move back in with family and worry about finances just as many were hoping to move past the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maisie Grattan, 21, left, and Evie Hargreaves, 22, at Ms. Hargreaves’ parents’ home, where they are both living temporarily as they face rising inflation.

item.title: Airbus and Air France Go on Trial Over 2009 Rio-Paris Crash
item.description: Families of the 228 victims fought for years to bring the companies to court. Both face manslaughter charges.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Alexandre Severo, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Wreckage recovered after the crash of Air France Flight 447 was brought ashore in Recife, Brazil, in 2009.

item.title: North Korea Says It Is Building Underwater Nuclear Weapons Silos
item.description: The country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, has inspected a recent flurry of missile tests, vowing to increase — and never give up — his nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media this week showed the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, monitoring a missile launch at an undisclosed location.

item.title: Striking Defense Lawyers in U.K. Agree to Return to Work
item.description: The government will increase legal aid fees by 15 percent for new and existing cases, ending a weekslong walkout.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Central Criminal Court of England and Wales (Old Bailey)
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Striking criminal barristers, the lawyers who argue cases in court, outside the Supreme Court in London in September.

item.title: Why Thailand’s Strict Gun Laws Did Not Keep It Safe
item.description: Firearm policy is tough for some people and lax for others, a recipe for problems. The horrific attack by an ex-policeman may spur calls for change, but it will not be easy.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave, Muktita Suhartono and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Andre Malerba for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners at Wat Rat Samakee, a temple in Naklang, Thailand, on Saturday, two days after a mass killing in and around a day care center. The attacker’s gun was obtained legally, the police said.

item.title: ‘Eye of Sauron’: The Dazzling Solar Tower in the Israeli Desert
item.description: Looming over a remote village in the Negev, the Ashalim solar plant is, for some, a marvel of green technology. For others, it’s a boondoggle and an eyesore.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Amit Elkayam
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shepherds near the Ashalim solar station. Completed in 2019, the tower generates enough electricity to power tens of thousands of homes.

item.title: In Face of Drought, the Netherlands Reserves Course to Save Water
item.description: As climate change dries out Europe, the Netherlands, a country long shaped by its overabundance of water, is suddenly confronting drought.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Rob Engelaar/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A cargo barge on the severely depleted Rhine River at Lobith, the Netherlands, in August, when the river’s discharge hit a record low.

item.title: What Russia’s Missile Strikes May Indicate About Its Weapons Stockpile
item.description: Russia’s assault on Ukraine on Monday raised questions about the capacity of Moscow’s forces to carry out President Vladimir V. Putin’s military calculations.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian rocket serves as a reminder of the relentless bombardment of Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Ukrainian Miners Rescued After Being Trapped by Russian Airstrikes
item.description: Dozens of miners in Kryvyi Rih spent hours trapped underground after strikes that left many areas without power, a local official said.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Enjoli Liston
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photo from May showing workers at the Metinvest Group Central Mining and Processing Plant in Kryvyi Rih, Ukraine, taking shelter in an underground bunker.

item.title: Russia’s Revenge
item.description: After weeks of setbacks on the battlefield, Russia struck civilian targets in Ukraine. But Vladimir Putin’s missiles may not accomplish much.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: It’s Never Too Late to Pivot From N.F.L. Linebacker to Neurosurgeon
item.description: When Myron Rolle was cut from the Pittsburgh Steelers, he fell into a funk until his mother reminded him of his two childhood dreams: Play football, then become a neurosurgeon. It was time for Plan B.
item.dc:creator: Elena Bergeron
item.media:credit: Ryan Christopher Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Myron Rolle became a neurosurgeon at Massachusetts General Hospital after his football glory days ended.

item.title: Russian forces targeted civilians in previous conflicts.
item.description: Russia’s attacks in Ukraine this week echo those of Moscow’s earlier military campaigns.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Joao Silva for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Georgian man looking at his apartment building that Russian bombing destroyed in 2008 in Gori.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Russia unleashes mass strikes on Ukrainian civilians.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising over Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, on Monday after the Russian bombardment.

item.title: British Official Stresses Threat From China Even Amid Russian Aggression
item.description: The head of Britain’s GCHQ spy agency warned that the West should not lose sight of the technological challenge from China as it deals with the immediate problem of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Jade Gao/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The director of Britain’s cyber and electronic intelligence agency said he was skeptical about how far China would go to support Russia’s aggression.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia’s Retaliatory Strikes on Ukraine
item.description: Plus North Korea’s underwater missile silos and trouble in the Metaverse.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Injured civilians at the scene of a Russian bombing in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: Biden Condemns Russia’s Missile Strikes on Ukraine
item.description: The president reaffirmed U.S. support for Ukraine, but did not announce any new steps in response to Russia’s missile strikes.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden earlier this month. He did not announce any new measures from the U.S. or its allies in response to the strikes.

item.title: Black Holes May Hide a Mind-Bending Secret About Our Universe
item.description: Take gravity, add quantum mechanics, stir. What do you get? Just maybe, a holographic cosmos.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: Leonardo Santamaria

item.title: Lukashenko Says Russian Troops Will Return to Belarus in Large Numbers
item.description: Statements by President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, an eccentric and highly erratic dictator, are rarely an accurate guide to current or future events.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Markus Schreiber/Associated Press
item.media:description: President Alexander Lukashenko at the Independence Palace in Minsk, Belarus, in May.

item.title: India and China Call for De-Escalation After Russian Strikes
item.description: Two key trading partners of Russia renewed calls for an end to the fighting, though they again did not directly criticize Moscow’s war.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vehicle that was destroyed in the attacks on Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, on Monday.

item.title: Russians React to Attacks in Ukraine
item.description: Some younger Russians expressed sadness about the missile strikes in civilian areas, but were not ready to put the blame squarely on the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A firefighter runs past residents evacuating from an apartment building in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, on Monday after a Russian attack.

item.title: In Kyiv, the strikes shattered what had become a relative sense of calm.
item.description: Russia’s attacks on Ukraine’s capital on Monday came after months in which the fighting had shifted to other parts of the country.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz

item.title: Putin says the strikes targeted Ukraine’s energy system.
item.description: Ukraine said Russian strikes had targeted energy facilities in 12 regions across the country.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Cora Engelbrecht and Andrés R. Martínez

item.title: Pro-Russian Figures Celebrate Ukraine Strikes as Revenge for Crimea Bridge
item.description: While many pro-Russian commentators have advocated a much tougher approach to the war, their calls grew louder as Russia suffered setbacks in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters extinguishing a blaze in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: Attacks on Ukraine’s Cities Come Days After Crimean Bridge Explosion
item.description: Ukrainians had been bracing for a severe Russian response after the main bridge linking Russia to Crimea was damaged over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: A passenger train traveling along the railway section of the bridge connecting Russia’s mainland and the Crimean Peninsula on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Repercussions from an attack on the bridge between Crimea and Russia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Alexey Pavlishak/Reuters

item.title: Landslides in Venezuela Leave at Least 22 Dead and Dozens Missing
item.description: The Venezuelan armed forces planned to deploy canines and drones to find missing residents and to deliver food and medicine.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Tibisay Romero
item.media:credit: Matias Delacroix/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mud coursed through the streets of Las Tejerías, Venezuela, over the weekend.

item.title: What We Know About Putin’s Nuclear Threats in Ukraine War
item.description: Comments from President Biden last week raised the issue for the first time in decades.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden, at an appearance in Hagerstown, Md., on Friday as his administration worked to soften his statements about nuclear war delivered at a fund-raiser the day before.

item.title: Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Gets Power Restored After Shelling
item.description: The leader of the International Atomic Energy Agency said getting the plant reconnected to outside power was a “temporary relief in a still untenable situation.”
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, along the banks of the Dnipro River in southern Ukraine, in August.

item.title: Ukrainians Fear Russian Reprisals for Crimea Bridge Attack
item.description: Bitter over a strike against a vital bridge, Moscow hit civilian areas of Ukraine with a barrage of rockets, and some Ukrainians feared worse to come.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia, Michael Schwirtz and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in trenches taken from Russian forces in the Kherson region on Saturday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Strikes Key City
item.description: Plus funerals for rampage victims in Thailand and a Covid spike in China
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.category: Madame Wu's Garden (Santa Monica, Calif, Restaurant)
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Flame and smoke rose from Crimean Bridge connecting Russian mainland and Crimean peninsula over the Kerch Strait, in Kerch, Crimea, on Saturday.

item.title: As Ukraine Forces Press Offensive, Front Line Is Shifting Fast
item.description: Evidence of killings and torture is discovered in a forest camp outside the village of Borova as Ukrainian soldiers recapture territory.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett

item.title: Putin Blames Ukraine For Crimea Bridge Blast, Calling It ‘Terrorism’
item.description: The Russian president’s remarks were his first about Saturday’s explosion on the Kerch Strait Bridge.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Sputnik via Reuters
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin in St. Petersburg, Russia, in a photo released by state media on Sunday.

item.title: Biden turns to lessons from the Cuban Missile Crisis to deal with Putin’s nuclear threat.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden said on Thursday that the world may be facing “the prospect of Armageddon” if Russia uses a tactical nuclear weapon.

item.title: Former Gov. Bill Richardson ‘Cautiously Optimistic’ About Griner’s Release
item.description: Bill Richardson, the former ambassador to the U.N., has been at odds with the White House over his private talks with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Seth Wenig/Associated Press
item.media:description: Bill Richardson in New York City in November of last year.

item.title: Russia Rushes to Restore Traffic After Crimea Bridge Explosion
item.description: An explosion a day earlier partly damaged the span and embarrassed the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Alexey Pavlishak/Reuters
item.media:description: Passenger cars driving on the Kerch Strait Bridge on Sunday.

item.title: The West Has a Migration Crisis. Why Does Rwanda Want to Help?
item.description: The small African nation has positioned itself as an altruistic partner of wealthier countries seeking to curb migration. But experts say Rwanda’s human rights record makes it no refuge for asylum seekers.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:credit: Brian Otieno for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Emergency Transit Mechanism Center in Gashora, Rwanda, houses African refugees awaiting asylum or resettlement elsewhere.

item.title: Greece Tries Stationing Police on Campus, and Students Fight Back
item.description: For decades, law enforcement was rarely allowed on university grounds. Critics say that putting officers there is part of a slide toward authoritarianism.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Dimitris Lampropoulos/NurPhoto, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Officers used tear gas in Athens last month to disperse students protesting the newly established university police force.

item.title: Ukraine wants a long-range American missile. The U.S. is holding it back.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:credit: Yonhap News Agency/Via Reuters
item.media:description: The Pentagon’s Army Tactical Missile Systems, or ATACMS, can strike targets 190 miles away.

item.title: North Korea’s Threat
item.description: Frustrated and isolated, the North is conducting more missile tests than ever.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A North Korean missile test in 2017.

item.title: Russians fleeing the draft find an unlikely haven in Central Asia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins

item.title: Deadly Shooting at Israeli Checkpoint Sets Jerusalem on Edge
item.description: Surging violence claimed the lives of four Palestinians and an Israeli soldier over the weekend, raising tensions on the eve of a Jewish holiday.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Ammar Awad/Reuters
item.media:description: Israeli security forces are seen after a deadly shooting at a checkpoint late Saturday in Jerusalem.

item.title: An American in Ukraine Finds the War He’s Been Searching For
item.description: For an unconventional former Marine colonel, Ukraine represents the morally just war that eluded him his entire career. But how much can he and his military start-up help?
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrew Milburn, founder of The Mozart Group, with Richie, a rescued mutt who has become the group’s mascot.

item.title: Blast on Crimean Bridge Deals Blow to Russian War Effort in Ukraine
item.description: Any impediment to traffic on the bridge could affect Russia’s ability to wage war in southern Ukraine, where Ukraine’s forces have been fighting an increasingly effective counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Black smoke billowed from a fire on the Kerch Strait Bridge that links Crimea to Russia on Friday.

item.title: 10 Dead in Gas Station Explosion in Ireland, Officials Say
item.description: A child and two teenagers were among those killed after an explosion in Creeslough, County Donegal, on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Brian Lawless/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The police said a girl, a teenage boy, a teenage girl, three women and four men died in the explosion in Creeslough.

item.title: Four Russian Missiles Strike Center of Kharkiv
item.description: Two building complexes used by the Ukrainian military appeared to be the targets.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers cleaned up debris after a piece of a shot-down missile fell into a park opposite its primary target, in central Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: The Purpose of Extra-Large Marshmallows? A U.K. Court Weighs In.
item.description: A British tribunal considered how a slightly larger marshmallow might be taxed by evaluating its taste, size and packaging.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Daniel Leal-Olivas — WPA Pool/Getty Images
item.media:description: A British tax tribunal examined marshmallows in detail, finding that ones slightly larger in size are “equally palatable” as a snack or roasted.

item.title: Many Canadians Can’t Afford Homes Despite Cooling Real Estate Market
item.description: Even in cities that were once considered a good bet for house hunters seeking affordability, affluent households find that prices are high.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nippun Goyal, 35, left, and his wife, Ritu Choudhary, 31, packing up their condo in Toronto for the move to Hamilton.

item.title: Children Killed in Thailand Massacre Are Laid to Rest
item.description: The town of Uthai Sawan in Thailand, a Buddhist-majority country, began formally mourning the victims of a mass killing at a day care center, most of them children.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Ryn Jirenuwat
item.media:credit: Andre Malerba for The New York Times
